title: Add input validation to resolve-command-id
description:
## Design Document
@docs/design/resolve-command-id-validation.md

## Overview
Add defensive input validation to the `resolve-command-id` function in commands.clj to prevent malformed shell commands from being executed. The function currently accepts any string and can produce invalid commands for edge cases like nil, empty strings, or incomplete prefixes.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. `resolve-command-id` throws `ExceptionInfo` for `nil` input
2. `resolve-command-id` throws `ExceptionInfo` for empty/blank string input
3. `resolve-command-id` throws `ExceptionInfo` for `"git."` (no subcommand)
4. `resolve-command-id` throws `ExceptionInfo` for `"bd."` (no subcommand)
5. `resolve-command-id` logs resolved command at debug level
6. All existing command resolution behavior unchanged for valid inputs
7. All new tests pass
8. All existing tests continue to pass

title: Create SelectableText component
description:
## Design Reference
@docs/design/selectable-text-component.md#component-api

## Context
This is the foundation task for the SelectableText feature. Creates the new cross-platform component that all view migrations will depend on.

## Requirements
- [ ] Create new file `ios/VoiceCode/Utils/SelectableText.swift`
- [ ] Implement `SelectableText` SwiftUI View wrapper with API:
  - `text: String` (required)
  - `isMonospaced: Bool = false`
  - `fontSize: CGFloat? = nil`
  - `textColor: Color? = nil`
- [ ] Implement `SelectableTextView_iOS` using UIViewRepresentable
- [ ] Implement `SelectableTextView_macOS` using NSViewRepresentable
- [ ] Handle dark mode via system label colors

## Technical Approach
- iOS: Wrap UITextView with isEditable=false, isSelectable=true, isScrollEnabled=false
- macOS: Wrap NSTextView.scrollableTextView() with isEditable=false, isSelectable=true
- Use platform conditionals (#if os(iOS) / #if os(macOS))
- Set text color to .label (iOS) / .labelColor (macOS) for dark mode support

Files to create:
- `ios/VoiceCode/Utils/SelectableText.swift`

Dependencies: None (this is the foundation task)

## Verification
- [ ] Build succeeds on iOS simulator
- [ ] Build succeeds on macOS
- [ ] Component can be instantiated in SwiftUI preview

## Acceptance Criteria
- Text appearance matches current rendering (font, size, color)
- No gray/disabled appearance on either platform
- Empty text does not crash
close_reason: Created SelectableText.swift with cross-platform UIViewRepresentable (iOS) and NSViewRepresentable (macOS) implementations. Supports text, isMonospaced, fontSize, and textColor parameters. Both iOS and macOS builds pass. All iOS tests pass; macOS unit tests pass (986 tests).

title: macOS Desktop Redesign
description:
## Design Document
@docs/design/macos-desktop-redesign.md

## Overview
Transform the macOS app from 'iOS app on Mac' into a native desktop experience. Implements persistent sidebar navigation, push-to-talk voice input, command palette, proper Settings scene, menu bar quick access, and information density adjustments while maintaining voice-first identity.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Sidebar persists while viewing conversation (NavigationSplitView)
2. Push-to-talk works with Option+Space anywhere in app
3. Command palette opens with Cmd+K and supports fuzzy search
4. Settings opens as separate window via Cmd+,
5. Menu bar icon shows connection status and enables quick voice capture
6. Information density is higher than iOS (smaller spacing, more visible content)
7. All keyboard shortcuts documented in menu items
8. iOS functionality remains unchanged (no regressions)
9. Session switching possible without losing conversation context
10. Voice input works seamlessly via both click and keyboard

## Implementation Phases
- Phase 1: Navigation Foundation (NavigationSplitView, SessionSidebarView)
- Phase 2: Settings & Keyboard (Settings scene, .commands{} shortcuts)
- Phase 3: Push-to-Talk (PushToTalkModifier, RecordingIndicator)
- Phase 4: Command Palette (CommandPaletteView)
- Phase 5: Menu Bar Extra (MenuBarContentView, sendQuickPrompt)
- Phase 6: Polish (DesktopDensity, hover states)

title: Add sendQuickPrompt method to VoiceCodeClient
description:
## Design Reference
@docs/design/macos-desktop-redesign.md#data-model-changes

## Context
The menu bar quick capture needs a simplified API to send prompts without managing full session lifecycle. This method creates a temporary session, sends the prompt, and returns the response.

## Requirements
- [ ] Add sendQuickPrompt(text:directory:completion:) method
- [ ] Create or reuse session in specified directory
- [ ] Send prompt via existing WebSocket infrastructure
- [ ] Return first response text via completion handler
- [ ] Handle errors by returning nil
- [ ] Track directory usage via AppSettings.trackDirectoryUsage

## Technical Approach
- Files to modify: ios/VoiceCode/VoiceCodeClient.swift
- Dependencies: AppSettings.trackDirectoryUsage

Method signature:
```swift
func sendQuickPrompt(text: String, directory: String, completion: @escaping (String?) -> Void)
```

Implementation approach:
1. Find or create session with matching workingDirectory
2. Set up one-time response handler
3. Send prompt message
4. On response, call completion with text
5. On error/timeout, call completion with nil
6. Call settings.trackDirectoryUsage(directory)

## Verification
- [ ] Unit test: completion called with response text on success
- [ ] Unit test: completion called with nil on error
- [ ] Integration test: prompt sent and response received
- [ ] Manual: Menu bar Send button triggers prompt and shows response

## Acceptance Criteria
- Menu bar icon shows connection status and enables quick voice capture (API support)

## Parallelization
Depends on: AppSettings.trackDirectoryUsage
Required by: MenuBarExtra (for sendPrompt functionality)
close_reason: Implemented sendQuickPrompt method with completion handler, timeout handling, directory tracking, and 6 passing tests

title: Create DesktopDensity utilities for information density
description:
## Design Reference
@docs/design/macos-desktop-redesign.md#6-information-density-adjustments

## Context
Desktop screens can display more information than mobile. This utility provides platform-specific constants and view modifiers for tighter spacing, smaller fonts, and higher truncation thresholds.

## Requirements
- [ ] Create DesktopDensity.swift with static constants struct
- [ ] Define spacing constants (listRowVerticalPadding: 4, listRowHorizontalPadding: 8)
- [ ] Define typography constants (bodyFont: 13pt, captionFont: 11pt)
- [ ] Define truncation threshold (2000 chars vs 500 on iOS)
- [ ] Define sizing constants (minRowHeight: 28, iconSize: 14)
- [ ] Create .desktopDensity() view modifier for font
- [ ] Create .desktopListRow() view modifier for padding
- [ ] Platform-guard with #if os(macOS)

## Technical Approach
- Files to create: ios/VoiceCode/Utils/DesktopDensity.swift
- Files to modify: Various view files to apply modifiers
- Dependencies: None (can be done independently)

View modifiers pattern:
```swift
extension View {
    @ViewBuilder
    func desktopDensity() -> some View {
        #if os(macOS)
        self.font(DesktopDensity.bodyFont)
        #else
        self
        #endif
    }
}
```

Apply to: SessionSidebarRow, MessageView (truncation), list rows

## Verification
- [ ] Manual: macOS rows are visually denser than iOS
- [ ] Manual: Font sizes are smaller but readable
- [ ] Manual: Long messages truncate at 2000 chars on macOS
- [ ] Visual comparison: Side-by-side iOS vs macOS screenshots

## Acceptance Criteria
- Information density is higher than iOS (smaller spacing, more visible content)

## Parallelization
Can be worked alongside: Any task after Phase 1
Should be applied after: SessionSidebarView, CommandPaletteView

Circle()

title: Implement PushToTalkModifier for Option+Space voice input
description:
## Design Reference
@docs/design/macos-desktop-redesign.md#2-push-to-talk-voice-input

## Context
Desktop users want hands-on-keyboard voice access. This modifier enables push-to-talk via Option+Space, starting recording on key down and stopping on key up.

## Requirements
- [ ] Create PushToTalkModifier.swift with ViewModifier protocol
- [ ] Accept VoiceInputManager as @ObservedObject parameter
- [ ] Track isHolding state to prevent repeated key events
- [ ] Handle .down phase: start recording if not already holding
- [ ] Handle .up phase: stop recording if was holding
- [ ] Ignore events without Option modifier
- [ ] Create View extension: .pushToTalk(voiceInput:)
- [ ] Platform-guard with #if os(macOS)

## Technical Approach
- Files to create: ios/VoiceCode/Utils/PushToTalkModifier.swift
- Files to modify: ios/VoiceCode/Views/ConversationView.swift
- Dependencies: MacOSRootView should exist for context

Key implementation:
```swift
.onKeyPress(" ", phases: [.down, .up]) { press in
    guard press.modifiers == .option else { return .ignored }
    // Handle down/up phases
}
```

ConversationView integration:
```swift
#if os(macOS)
.pushToTalk(voiceInput: voiceInputManager)
#endif
```

## Verification
- [ ] Unit test: Option+Space down calls startRecording(), sets isHolding true
- [ ] Unit test: Option+Space up calls stopRecording(), sets isHolding false
- [ ] Unit test: Space without Option returns .ignored
- [ ] Manual: Hold Option+Space starts recording with visual feedback
- [ ] Manual: Release stops recording and shows transcription

## Acceptance Criteria
- Push-to-talk works with Option+Space anywhere in app
- Voice input works seamlessly via both click and keyboard
